class_notes:
"Novel Worlds: History & Politics in Fiction" | This course has two broad aims: first, it will introduce students to a selection of compelling narratives from around the world; and second, it will encourage a meditation on the link between history and fiction or politics and aesthetics in novelistic writing. In this course, as we consider several elements in narrative form and fictionality (tale, fantasy, crime fiction, metafictional historiography, postcolonial rewriting), we will also look at each novel's mediation and revision of their respective political and cultural histories and ask in what ways narrative and aesthetics offer alternative past and future visions. Questions for discussion will include "colonialism/postcolonial writing/decoloniality," "translation," "globalization and cosmopolitanism," "state, secularism, and religion," "migration and engagement with 'others'," "violence, trauma, and memory," "gender and sexual identity." Through readings, discussions, and writing assignments, we will explore how a comparative and international perspective enables us to read and interpret novels (even the most seemingly "local" or "national" productions) as irresistibly "global." We will also analyze how certain novelistic forms, themes and issues "travel."


Required texts or materials to be purchased:
-	Naguib Mahfouz, Arabian Nights and Days (240 p)
-	Orhan Pamuk, My Name is Red (417 p)
-	Assia Djebar, Fantasia: An Algerian Cavalcade, Trans. Dorothy S. Blair (Heinemann, 1993, 227 p)
-	Abdulrazak Gurnah, Paradise (Bloomsbury, 2022, 256 p)
-	Tahar Ben Jelloun, The Sand Child (176)
-	Adania Shibli, Minor Detail (140 p)


Assessment and grading (exams, quizzes, assignments, essays, papers, attendance):
-	Weekly blogs
-	In-Class Presentation
-	Close-reading paper (3-4 pages)
-	Comparative paper (5-6 pages)
course_description: An introduction to different methods of literary criticism and textual interpretation, applying a variety of theoretical approaches to selected literary texts.  Readings include essays, fiction, poetry, and drama. *Note: This course is non-repeatable.
